text: <@U01EYDA8345> That is not what I meant, actually on general thread  <@U01FSSHULHE> asked as well similar question. Someone mentioned of using Tableau app to visual data, and yes back in 2015 I started to use it as well, just google "Betfair Tennis Trading and Data Visualization" and you find maybe my blog post about. So my question was how you use this python library in back-testing/data analyzing and bot testing? Can you show short video of workflow from beck-tesing to bot execution. My point is that as all of you maybe, I am open to any new suggestions and can learn something new. What I am for these days is find simple way to data visualization.

text: I use ELK stack. Send data to elasticsearch (just json) and visualize it via Kibana. Something like this - <https://monosnap.com/file/hDmU7d7ZueQZjn4E4JIx8jShY3oIgM>

text: Im not using this python library. I have wirtten my own libs to fit my needs. As a result I get an ecxel file with graphs and all data I need to understand what is going on. Maybe I can show it later to you if that is what you want to see.

text: <@U013R0E7SUV> yes, that is what I meant. My app for data analyzing is desktop wpf but charting is done through javascript libraries like highcharts or plotly. Why, because using wpf charts needs more coding, and in some cases I failed to implement what I wanted. So I still am looking for charting libraries with easy api, the best way is just use json data. Have you got experiences with other javascript libraries, some stock analyzing web site use? App has access to data, and implements scripting so charts can be generated by small scripts. Better to watch short video <https://youtu.be/5oi_JwFi3e4> to understand what I mean. <@U01EYDA8345> yes, if you have got time to make short video I would like to see Excel charting, if it has some advantage I can integrate Excel charting to my app.

text: Main issue Kibana, Tableau etc not only visualization tool, this is analytics tool - its allow easy add any type of filters, allow add some extra data like avg, mean,rolling mean, std and other. So, in this case not make any sense use just visualization libs. Perhaps I missed the topic of discussion, but for me the most correct thing would be to simply export the data to the necessary technology stack and use tools that are designed for data analytics, and not try to build my own plots

text: <@U013R0E7SUV> Andrej yes I am looking for any tool helping to visualize or analyze, but when you end with last phase, so implementing bot data analyzing algorithm, you need  to use the same algorithm for data processing like your used tool is using, and that can be sometimes a problem. This way the code preprocessing data for visualization or analyzing can be used directly in the bot trigger, you can actually see that in my video where back-testing strategy/so bot, generates data to be shown on the charts, so helping me manually looking for some data patterns.

elements.text: Andrej yes I am looking for any tool helping to visualize or analyze, but when you end with last phase, so implementing bot data analyzing algorithm, you need  to use the same algorithm for data processing like your used tool is using, and that can be sometimes a problem. This way the code preprocessing data for visualization or analyzing can be used directly in the bot trigger, you can actually see that in my video where back-testing strategy/so bot, generates data to be shown on the charts, so helping me manually looking for some data patterns.

text: <@U013MLED3V1> I don't want to be negative, great job. But I don't see a way to use such a tool to be honest. What's the point of looking at separate markets? Does it allow you to select several thousand or better tens of thousands of markets and build various averaged charts for all of them? To really see the patterns. Better yet, it would show anomalies - i.e. singled out from these thousands of markets sets of markets that differ from others in some way. By the way, this allows by tool like Kibana

text: Most of my experience is using cython, to the extent that I would say “don’t do that”, since it paints you into a corner so often.
